Description: Limestone tomb relief: this slab, which is carved in good, low relief, contains the lowest register and part of the register above from a wall exhibiting scenes of offering and the preparation of sacrifices. The bottom register contains representations of the ritual slaying and dismemberment of four oxen. Above is the lower half of a register which contained figures of offering-bearers. In front of each figure is a raised panel where the name of the person shown should have been carved in low relief. Three names only have been scratched roughly on three of the panels: Neferihy (?), Hau, and Itisen.
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Egypt, Synopsis 1835 says: "It was found near Sakkara, four leagues from Grand Cairo. "
Curator's comments: Bibliography. The British Museum, 'A guide to the Egyptian galleries (Sculpture)' (London, 1909), p. 22; The British Museum, 'Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, &c., in the British Museum' Part 6 (London, 1922), pl. 16; 'Toros. Image i culte a la mediterránia antiga : [exposició a Barcelona, Saló del Tinell, Barcelona, del 14 de noviembre de 2002 al 6 de marzo de 2003 / coordinació de Lina Ubero, Quim Vicente]' (Barcelona, 2002), 400-401, Cat. No. 188.
Bibliographic references: James 1961 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc. Part 1 (pl.4)
Barcelona 2002 / The Bull in the Mediterranean World (cat.188, p.214)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: Exhibition: "The Bull in the Ancient World / Bulls: Image and Cult in the ancient Mediterranean", Salo del Tinell, Barcelona, 14 Nov 2002-13 Feb 2003; then Benaki Museum, Athens, 14 Nov 2002-7 Jun 2003.
Condition: Good, apart from a very few slightly damaged areas.
Acquisition name: Donated by: John Stuart, 3rd Earl of Bute
